awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Hybrid Discrete-Continuum Numerical Simulation of Granular Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1706689
PI: Grinspun, Eitan

The flow of granular materials is important in many manufacturing processes, especially in the pharmaceutical, energy, and agricultural industries, and in naturally-occurring processes such as avalanches, landslides and sediment transport.  Modeling the behavior of flowing granular materials is challenging because observable measurable properties of the flowing material depend on microscopic dynamics on the scale of the individual grains of the material.  In the absence of reliable models, the design of equipment to handle granular materials is often based on heuristic approaches, which are not optimal and occasionally lead to catastrophic failures.  This award will support a new framework for predicting the dynamics of granular systems that addresses small-scale and large-scale phenomena at the same time.  The new framework will be a hybrid approach that combines models of granular materials as fluids with models of granular materials as collections of discrete particles.  The key challenge that will be addressed is to discover the appropriate way to combine these approaches in a hybrid model that accurately simulates well-defined prototype granular flows and is validated against comparisons with industrial and geological scale granular flow phenomena.  Computer codes that are generated in the project will be shared publicly, and the research team will engage students at various academic levels to participate in the project, especially students from traditionally underrepresented groups.

A hybrid framework for simulating granular flows will be developed to obtain the efficiency of continuum simulations at the macroscale and the accuracy and precision of discrete particle simulations offer at the microscale.  Four components of the hybridization scheme will be explored: a coupling procedure that mechanically handshakes the continuum regime and the particle regime along a reconciliation zone, a homogenization operator that replaces a discrete element zone with a continuum state, an enrichment operator that acts in the opposite direction, and an oracle that determines where it is safe to homogenize and where enrichment to discrete grains is needed.  Components of the scheme will be separately tested and validated against analytical results and experimental data.  The overall hybrid model will then be validated against large-scale granular phenomena with the goal of accurately simulation flows up to the industrial- and geo-scales.  The results of this work and its associated computer codes will be made available to practitioners and researchers in industry and geosciences and to developers of cinematic realizations of granular flow phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
Many granular flow problems of interest in industry and geomechanics involve billions of grains, far too many to simulate individually using discrete element methods (DEM).  The alternative is to use a continuum method, which has fewer degrees of freedom by homogenizing over batches of grains.  However, these methods require an accurate and robust constituive relation, which is very challenging to obtain due to the many complexities of granular flows.  This project aimed to develop a "best of both worlds" solution by creating a hybrid approach for granular flow simulation in which the subdoamin is divided into a continuum region, a DEM region, and a reconciliation zone where the two zones overlap and pass information.  The key idea is to represent as much of the domain as possible with a fast continuum respresentation, and identify the tricky regions and ensure those are treated with DEM. 

Because granular materials undergo enormous deformations, a key requirement is that the domain splitting be adpative as the flow proceeds; as time goes on, a region that once required DEM may be amenable to a continuum representation and conversely, a material part that was previously represented as a continuum may need to be enriched  into "real" grains.  These homogenization and enrichment operators require careful detailing.  This is especially so for enrichment, which requires creating a small packet of grains with some desired upscaled continuum properties, and which fits correctly into the space it is allotted.

Lastly, a major challenge of this project was to determine one or more "oracles".  The oracle is an algorithm that persistently monitors the flow and determines based on a set of criteria how to patition the domain between discrete and continuum zones.  The oracle must be trained to identify certain features that are known to be challenging to basic continuum models.  Our work in this project focused on two oracles:  one that identifies material near walls or free surfaces, and another that watches for the initiation of shear-bands (zones of highly conentrated flow).  These features/regions are all known to be very difficult to simulate correctly with continuum methods.

Throughout our study, the discrete domain was solved using spherical, frictional, viscoelastic grains.  The continuum domain was numerically implemented using the meshless Material Point Method (MPM).  The constituive law chosen was a very simple frictional plastic model with no tension allowed.

We were able to demonstrate using our wall/boundary oracle, that the method can produce significant speedup over pure DEM in a variety of test cases, including the runout of heaps, rotating drums, hopper flows, excavation, and driving over sands.  In each of these cases the speedup was due to the DEM domain only including zones near free surfaces or solid-body boundaries.  We developed a theoretical curve showing how the hybrid approach fairs against pure DEM as the problem size and zone-splitting specificities change.  This approach has a direct usage in graphics applications, since the DEM domain is always on the outside, which is the part the eye sees.

Development of the shear-band orcale required many considerations.  Many previous approaches used local strain to determine if a region is part of a shear-band.  However, granular flow problems often have a well-developed or steady state of flow where everywhere has undergone a lot of strain.  So instead we developed a routine that flags elements having two things simulateneusly: (i) The relative Laplacian of the shear rate (scaled by local shear-rate and particle size), and (ii) the amount of strain recently accumulated.  On top of this orcale, we also developed a specialized enrichment routine.  After the oracle flags a region of the continuum to be enriched, the preimage of the region in the original configuration is identified, and packed with grains.  A mini DEM simulation is then run in which the boundaries of that subregion are forced to move as the continuum once did.  When this is done, grains fill the needed space at the current time and have the "experiential training" of the deformation needed for them to possess the right internal state.  This approach was tested in multiple problems including biaxial compression banding, simple shearing, and indenter penetration.  In each case, solutions obtained from the hybrid algorithm agreed with DEM but were obtained much faster since only the zones undergoing concentrated shearing are enriched with grains and the bulk of the problem was solved as a continuum.
